addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my singular good Lord the L. Burghley Lord highe Treasuro
r
of England

9 May
1590
M
r
Bodeley to my L./.

page.lettertext:
fol.144r
It may please yo
r
L. to be advertised, that
fower daies past, I receaved yo
r
L. letter w
t
certaine specialties about
e sute of
Cap
t
Bornstra
:
whiche I will manifest heere, as ether
e states,
or
e Captain himself shall minister occasion. I
have also receaved from
e
Generall states
, a
copie of their letter to my
LL. of
e Councell
, in
answear to that Proposition w
ch
I lastly made unto
them. But seing it hath pleased her
Ma
tie
to re-
solve uppon my
L. of Buckhurstes
comming hither,
I should but troble yo
r
L. to note
e untruth and
impertinencie, of certaine bold assertions, w
ch
their
answear conteneth. And therfore I referre both
that, and all other matters, to his L. arrival: who
being heere in place, shall more easely discerne their
perverse proceedinges, then I by my letters can any
way explane. They have bin suffered over long
to practise w
t
e Provinces, and to winne
e affections
of divers, by their wrong informac
o
ns: for whiche
I stand in dout, whether by his L. comming the
state of this government will be so reformed, as
it should be, and to her Ma
ties
contentment. Never-
theles I am fully assured, that it will availe very
muche, to keepe
e people at her Ma
ties
devotion,
and to effect in many thinges a great deale of
good. I doe finde that yo
r
L. hath had
some speeche w
t
M
r
Ortel
. For he hath sent a
copie to
e
Councel
heere, of
e last Apostils, whiche
he receaved from my LL. of
e Councel,
e 15.
of Marche: excusing himself, for
at he had sent
them long before to
e Advocat
Barnevelt
, and
supposed that they had bin imparted by him to
e
Councel of state. The self same course is
fol.144v
taken by their Agent in
Fraunce
, who never writeth
hither to
e Councel, from whome he receaved his
Commission and instructions, but to Barnevelt.
Howe muche
e affaires of
e Councel, and
e publick
service is hindred by suche kinde of dealing, it is
nowe considered of heere, more then ever before: and
theruppon divers of
e Councel have addressed
their complaintes, aswell for those, as for other in-
dignities offered unto them, to their several Pro-
vinces. Of that whiche hath bin attempted,
and is further intended against
e towne of
Nieu-
meghen
, because
S
r
Francis Vere
being there, hath
written at large, I neede not certifie yo
r
L.
The 5 of this moneth
Count Maurice
came before
it in very good order, w
t
intention to fortifie, and
to besiege it. The 2 of this moneth
Count
Mansfelt
brought 8 peeces of great Artillerie,
before
e litele sconce of Nordame, whiche is situat
at
e point of
e haven, that leadeth towardes the
sea, from
Sevenberghen
. The third day, after a
long batterie, and a sufficient breache made, he
assaulted it by boate, both
e same day, and
e
next: but was valiantly repulsed at both times,
w
t
the losse of many of his best souldiers. There
were w
t
in
e Fort to
e nomber of 300 men, w
ch
were
often
often changed and refreshe d by the
Count of Solmes
, who lay at hand uppon
e water,
and had alwaies
e meanes, both by day and night,
to put in men and victual. Moreover the
5 of this moneth, in
e night time,
e Enemie at-
empted by boate to enter
e
Hillen
, a port of
e
Ile of
Williamstat
, over against Sevenberghen:
from whens notw
t
standing he was forced to retire,
w
t
the losse of
e boate, and most of those that
fol.145r
were in it. The report is uncertaine of the
full nomber slaine on
e Enemies side: but we
make account of 500 at
e lest, and of fewe
of o
r
owne. The 7 of his moneth we
were advertised,
at
e Enemie intended to leave
e siege, and to
mache
marche w
t
all his forces
in those quarters, both of horse and forte, whiche
are esteemed 7000 to relieve
e towne of Nieu-
meghen. There is newly come unto them
e regi-
ment of
S
r
William Standly
, to
e nomber, as we
heare, of 600.
And thus I take my humble
leave. From
e
Haghe
.
e 9 of May. 90
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
